instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello everybody :) 

actually  I struggle at an old Macbook Pro (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B).
Is takes 19-20 mA and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is missing (40mV).

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR> i got <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.37V and <SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_SS</SIGNAL> 3.34V.
I need some hints why my PP3V3 is so low :-/

Thank you
dudipupan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Which is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
Are you using original 85W charger?
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> voltage.

Is the battery charging?
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?
Also try to start with charger and battery connected.

Check the 4 PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable with 12.73V.
I already tried it with the original 85W charger but in general i'm using a 10A PSU on 18.5V.
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is also low (~10mV)

The battery is chargin.
Didn't tried SMCbypass mode yet.
Dows not tun on with charger and battery connected.

The 4 RTC signals:

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.35V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>: 3.35V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>: 3.05V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>: 3.25V

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3_PCH</SIGNAL>: 3.35V

I noticed now that if i connect battery and charger for some time (~5 min) the fans start spinning for ~1second repeatedly all 3 seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Try with known good working battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is it normal that this MBP only powering on with a battery connected? Got several MBP from 2009/2010 not powering on without battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
The board should start without battery, but needs 85W charger.
However, battery is required for proper work pn this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So I just looked again at this problem (with a new battery and still not powering on) and measured the RTC signals again:

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>: 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>: 3.05V <---- seems not stable... slowly decreasing.
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>: 3.25V <---- seems not stable... slowly decreasing.

Also tried SMC bypass mode - without success.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Maybe also interesting: 
Battery is only charging when i connect the battery first.
On other boards the battery is also charging when I connect the battery after the magsafe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
These boards have strange behaviour without battery, or fake chinese battery.

RTC signals look good.
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> still missing?
You can test with 2011 battery, if original not available.

BTW, do not force your luck connecting/disconnecting battery once charger is present.
SMC can be damaged through I2C battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have tried it already with all batteries for 15" MBP i got ? Known good original ones and new third party ones.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is still missing ?

Okay, that is good to know, thank you ? Will try to avoid it in future ?
